comments.commentBody: This article is not well written. Also, such a small study is not worthy of coverage in the NYT. Finally, I disagree that the women thought about the men "incessantly." Do the researchers (or Pamela Paul) mean to tell us that from the minute women wake up to the minute they go to sleep they are thinking about the men who may or may not like them without pause, and then when they go to sleep those men are still in their subconscious thoughts? Please. I doubt that the human brain is capable of holding the same thought incessantly.
Very Interesting - like MOL and 5:30 am, I had YOUR Mouth first too.

Just got around to this one. Solved it clean (I don't Google) but for the SE, where KNAR and TRIMSPA blew up a completion. KNAR is just arcana for the sake of arcana, IMHO, and TRIMSPA takes the use of brand names over the line for me. TOYOTA? Sure. LEICA? Fine. TRIMSPA? Nah.
Sorry, but I give this an 80, even allowing for the very clever OSCARBUZZ and ONEBALL.
(And TIMUR I knew, but ULALUME? Never heard that word or seen it in my life.)

Loved every minute of it! Someone said that puns are the worst form of humor. Then spoonerisms must follow just behind.

Happy little washday song"

Enjoyed every moment of this puzzle. It atoned for last week's Saturday puzzle.

Michael Young is emminently available and the Mets are so desperate that they're trying to convert a defensively-challenged outfielder/first baseman into a keystone contributor.  What does this tell you?

Several years ago, my boss came to my classroom unannounced to observe a lesson.  Afterwards, we had a school emergency.  When I went to drop off some items that he needed at the end of the day, he confessed that the emergency took so much out of him and would I write a summary for him.  I wrote it as an observation.  To my surprise, he change just one word and submitted it.  When two professionals share a candid and truthful opinion of a personnel matter, this should be fine.
I enjoyed this very much.  A good story of a very good, and strong, family. Thank you.

An excellent and interesting piece by a writer who is clearly and the height of his powers.  One nit:  the NYT deriding other news organizations as "once-serious" is a bit pot/kettleish for my tastes...

When I click on FireFox to get on the internet, my home page is my hometown newspaper, "The State" out of South Carolina. I hesitate to call it a newspaper because of it's lack of facts in it's news reporting, but there are times when it does a creditable job on some local stories.
I next go to the NY Times and check out the headlines and stories covered on the web page, take a mental note of the stories or columnist I want to read. I then go directly to the opinion page, read the editorials and the columnists then return to the home page to read some of the stories making headlines.
My next stop is, wait for it, the New York Daily News, for some interesting gossip and some hard NYC stories.
My other stops during the day, when I have time, is The New Yorker, The Washington Post, Mother Jones, and The Southern Poverty Law Center, to name a few.
I find the print media that I trust start with you and move on from there.
Good article, and I like the fact that you are unimpressed about your status as "and important" person.

Perhaps those who accuse Jillian of "bullying" have an aversion to a strong, assertive woman who is passionate about helping the morbidly obese break through years-long negative patterns of destructive thinking, rationalization, or despair? Do you think this is just going to happen by saying "please" and "would you consider changing?" I'm going to say it - not all yelling is bad.

If you actually have watched her programs ("Biggest Loser" and "Losing it With Jillian" last summer) you would know that (1) the yelling is a calculated tactic to break through the denial and challenge people to confront some uncomfortable truths about themselves, where they're coming from,where they're at, and where they're headed if they don't change, NOW, and to motivate them to get going/keep going instead of quitting when it gets tough; and (2) She also balances the yelling by showing a commendable degree of empathy and compassion for those she's working with. She genuinely cares for these folks,wants them to be healthy in all ways, and is passionate about helping this society heal from our national epidemic of obesity and related physical and emotional illness. She has changed so many lives and brought hope to so many people... I know our family, which is not badly off at all regarding health, has been inspired by her to make many positive changes regarding nutrition and exercise, changes that will impact us for a lifetime and enable us to give back so much more to our networks, large and small. She is certainly not a saint, but she IS a woman who has the courage and passion to try to make a difference where it matters. For that I respect her profoundly, and am glad my teenage daughter looks up to her as a role model. I do, too.

I know the show is rigged to look dramatic, but I've always wondered why she and Bob consider themselves equipped to do therapy with these obese people.  They aren't licensed therapists as far as I know.  I get the fact that obesity is usually covering other issues, but screaming at someone until they comply and cry doesn't seem healthy to me.
The movie is not about married people.  It is about an engaged couple.  And is actually very pro-monogamy.
Um, you don't need to be monogamous to be happily married.

I want to thank Danny Hakim and the New York Times for doing the job of real journalists. This is investigative journalism at its best. You have brought sunlight in which is the best disinfectant.
Already Governor Cuomo has fired the heads of the branch responsible to keep this problem in the
public eye and to stamp out abuses. Mr. Hakim exposed the ways the workers and agencies were trying to
cover their tracks and to retaliate against a conscientious aide. Law enforcement needs to be brought in to
do proper evaluations of abuse complaints. As stated above, the community should be more involved and independent advocates appointed. Thank you Danny Hakim. Please keep it up!

Great fun! My favorite answer was "MARRYING THE KALE." It's the absurdity that made me laugh, and laughing that made my morning.
For Suzy M #24, Tiger and Leopard are the names given to some new technological wizardry, a smart phone or PDA or something of that nature.

I live in a group home because of epilepsy! Graduated last May with 3 degrees after having brain surgery 8 years ago, yet still seizure. I am due to start my Masters in Fall. I am vice chair of my neighborhood board for the past 3 years. I have witnessed abuse and have been abused myself, most recently especially. I am reading this article while having planned to go to my State legislator tomorrow with a complaint against the home and State licensed owners! I have assisted these owners but I will not accept their abuse and harassment, nor the other clients in the house. If the owners fail to do their jobs I will make sure the State does it's job in forming an oversight board or commission for these homes in the State of Hawaii! If not, I go the Feds with a federal case for assistance!

This is the most frightening article I've read, ever!  We are all at risk to have this happen if we do not have an plan or family or money and become mentally or physically ill.  We cannot expect the 'State' to help us.  Some of us cannot even except family members to help either.  I applaud the NY governor for looking into this horific situation.

As a California-licensed private fiduciary, I'm glad to see this coming to light. It's a dreadful situation. The same problems exist regarding care of the elderly, mentally ill and children. In all cases, abuse - whether verbal, physical, emotional, mental or other - should be responded to with vigorous prosecution by the district attorney. This is not a civil issue - it is criminal.

Solutions include 1.) Increase worker qualifications, 2.) Combine community facilities into EU-type mid-sized 'dorms' where people with similar needs can receive better and varied programs, 3.) Establish supervision methods that work, including performance plans for every employee, 4.) Create a state administrator who oversees all programs and reports directly to the governor.

Thank you to the journalists and editors of the New York Times - this story is a tremendous public service.

From the lead, I was waiting for a statement like this:

"The state initiated termination proceedings in 129 of the cases reviewed but succeeded in just 30 of them, in large part because the workers’ union, the Civil Service Employees Association, aggressively resisted firings in almost every case. A few employees resigned, even though the state sought only suspensions."

This is why people have stop believing in unions.

This piece made me ill. I could not read the entire article. My heart goes out to the victims of the abuse. There is plenty of guilt to go around. The vulnerable victims have been failed by many. Charges should be brought against the former head of the agency, not just a slap on the wrist. Transferring abusers reminds me all too well of the transfer of abusers in the Catholic Church.
Does anyone of these people ever stop and think "this could be MY child, my brother, my sister, my mother, my cousin- ME ??!

Apparently not.
It is time to get rid of unions, pure and simple.They have outlived their usefulness and have become nothing more than expensive burdens and far worse in terms of protecting clear predators.

The next place that the Times should shed its investigative journalistic light on should be the short term psychiatric units in hospitals,including prominent ones in the New York area . I know for a fact that staff abuse of vulnerable patients is going on there.

I worked with individuals with developmental disability in Canada and now in the state of NY. After reading the article, there's a lot of disturbing issues mentioned that needs to be addressed. One issue that  troubles me most are the union's defense of staff who are repeat offenders.  It is unacceptable that a staff who was known to have abused an individual with developmental disability was allowed to remain in the job. The reasoning "It is our job" doesn't make sense. How can they go on with their life knowing that the person they defended to remain in job can and had repeatedly abused individuals with developmental disability? How would they feel if the individual with developmental disability is their son/daughter?

Why has Obama not prosecuted one of these bankers?  Could it be because nine of his top ten contributors were among those bankers?  Obama cannot be trusted to do what is right.  He is in the pocket of the Wall Street bankers.  There should be , right now , hundreds of bankers being prosecuted.  Under Obama, there is not one.

Those who continue to believe we live in a democracy rather than an oligarchy have not been paying attention these last three or four decades. Krugman has been paying attention, and trying to inform us. So did Lewis Lapham, in The Saturday Review, decades ago. But, as Ronald Reagan said, "Americans have a right to be stupid if they want to be." He said nothing of the tragedy they bring upon themselves.

Well put. Sadly, the main lesson of "Inside Job" is that the Republican and Democratic parties were (and are) equally complicit in the dishonest, graft.

America has suffered through many financial collapses over the years spurred by corrupt bankers, but this is the first without criminal prosecutions.

Innumerable experts, from William Black to Joseph Sitgliz, have called out the Big 13 banks for outright crimes. Federal judges have asked Obama admin lawyers from the bench, "How is it possible that a bank can commit a crime for a decade yet not a single bank executive is being charged?" States' attorneys general have complained that Feds are discouraging them from prosecuting mortgage fraud.

Yet the Obama administration continues to do everything it can to protect the Big 13 banks -- financially, legally, legislatively, PR-wise.

Where is the "change we need"?
